XH1mfzpsV9tDBJOIqQ8BTw.text: Fresh, clean, vibrant, healthy, beautiful...loved it. Line was long so expect to wait. Worth it. I got a crab bowl and it was good, corn fritters were a great share. Enjoyed it

mGToqmWP61GI85D69IvCIA.text: Popped in for brunch after a facial close by. This place was bustling and at times had a line. We sat at the bar and had the sweetest server imaginable. I ordered scrambled eggs, toast, avocado relish, chips, and tomatoes. Everything was absolutely perfect. The eggs?!? Witchcraft! How did they make them so pretty and amazing?? I consider this to be the most fulfilling brunch I've had over my multiple visits to London. I want to try the ricotta pancakes next time; they looked incredible! PS came here a second time and it is crawling with children and buggies. Not quite a reflection of the restaurant but the clientele. I don't like being surrounded by kiddos so I don't know if I'll come back.

vwol-xPR3_ZQcfJhKEKC5Q.text: Minus one star for the high prices. However, everything else is 5 stars:- The ambiance is beautiful, bright and clean.- Service was lovely. I never had an issue flagging someone down but I had time to enjoy my food and my book. I sat at the bar as a solo diner on a Monday morning so I didn't really have to wait, either. - Coffee was excellent, and the ricotta pancakes were delicious!!I came here on a trip to London and will definitely be back if possible. I need to try those physics defying eggs.

Uk95-Ble84UTBXZJYT7LKA.text: The food is fantastic here! Waiting in line is an utter pain in the butt so definitely get there early or go for a late (i mean after 2pm) brunch.If you don't order the ricotta hotcakes you're making a mistake!Enjoy!

_Lwc7VPW-rGYUjBxzWwSXw.text: Very busy. I've been twice and the food was average, probably due to high traffic and being understaffed. Not worth waiting for vs other places nearby.

6QEX8SnemT_iGTST9sfiOQ.text: The most healthiest meal i have ever had falling in love with the scrumble eggs & chicken salad also the fruit with greek yogurt the taste is so so gddd !

9sReebNdwgsxnF0Wc3CItg.text: Absolutely love this place!  It's packed if you go on the weekends or too late in the morning, but that's no fault of the restaurant's - just the consequence of having a good reputation and being in Notting Hill.  My best advice would be to go a bit earlier or during the week to beat the queues.  I've gone at 9:30 on a Saturday morning with a group of four and been seated straight away.The restaurant is bright & inviting and feels more like a sunny cafe or bistro than a fancy restaurant - although the food reminds you that it is.  Everything I've tried here has been fantastic.  I usually try to go with a bunch of friends or with my family when they visit just so we can all order different things and sample more!The ricotta hotcakes are as good as everyone says, but I like a bit of savory with my breakfast so I usually go for the sweetcorn fritters or the full Aussie.  Either way, you can't go wrong!

imOW5hThd4AB-e8oecEeaQ.text: I am a little confused about what the fuss is all about.  The space is beautiful and on a sunny day is very inviting.  We ended up sitting at the bar so you don't get to enjoy the space as much and I think the service at the bar is pretty crap.  I ordered the ricotta cakes because I heard they were all the rage.  I thought they were boring and not all that exciting to eat.  We also ordered a chopped salad and while it was executed well it was nothing special and was just well cut well blanched veggies with nothing of flare.I think there are better brunch places in town.....

CxDljK4qRPdmGwkXzrL9Yw.text: It's pricey, but it is London and the food is very, very nice. I had the brown rice and miso porridge with mango, and my partner the scrambled eggs with a side of avocado. We also had a few drinks and in total it was around £32. I wouldn't usually spend this on a breakfast but we are on holiday so it a treat. And we do plan to return before leaving London - it's was that good. The place was packed when we visited on a mid-week morning around 9.30am, but we got seated quickly because we were happy to sit at the bar. If you want a table, you might need to wait. Service was quick too, but we didn't feel rushed to leave.

nVazTMniBzNms2d8mPK6Hg.text: Came here on a Monday afternoon so I didn't have to deal with the queue or the crowds. The space is lively and inviting, but it was quite packed even on a weekday, so we were seated rather close to our neighbours. Service was ok, we got our seat, menu and bill at a reasonable pace, so it was definitely not as terrible as other yelpers make it out to be.We got the open steak sandwich and the ricotta hotcakes, and both were great. The ingredients were fresh, and I was pleasantly surprised by the portion. Loved the honeycomb butter and the generous amount of ricotta cheese in the hotcakes. Would definitely come back to try their our dishes.

gEjVv19oNAgeLSTmV-KvAQ.text: Super busy, of course, worth the wait. The ginger cake is out of this world, so are the green juice and the chia seed pudding. Coffee super tasty. Staff friendly and very helpful despite the business of te spot. Now overall I find it a bit pretentious. But that's my humble opinion... :D

Zh0Rx4HKv0IutqZtDkdwgA.text: Sadly having now already visited Granger and mentioned our not so great experience to friends, they've informed me that they could have told me that...wish they had, to have saved my time!We ventured here last weekend, after having it bookmarked for ages, around brunch time on Saturday.  We were seated quickly, but at a not so great cramped table, when there were plenty of better options, but rather than being difficult, we took it...took awhile to get menus, but when we did we ordered quickly - a bloody for me (extra spicy), a salad with variations for my boyfriend.The bloody arrived as clearly just tomato juice (plus hopefully vodka), but nothing else...so my boyfriend went up to the bar to ask for worcestershire sauce, lemon juice, pepper, hot sauce.....which once added, made a much better bloody.  My boyfriend wasn't too wild about his salad at first, but said it grew on him.Unfortunately, things got worse from there.  After sitting for ages saying we were ready to close out, the bill still hadn't arrived....so we asked our server again...she again said ok, then i see her clearing a table behind us (the place was pretty empty at that point, so no need to rush to clear and set tables)....so after another 5 or so minutes, we ask her again for the bill....she says ok...then i see her clearing ANOTHER table, setting ANOTHER table...and still no bill.  This process continued, and we ultimately asked her four times, and about 15 minutes (or more) to get our bill...for a salad and a bloody.At that point, we were in a rush to get elsewhere, which ultimately got us there over an hour later than we'd planned.  Plus, when she FINALLY brought the bill she's all trying to shoot the shit with us ("anything fun planned for tonight?"...um, now we'll be hauling ass to get somewhere in time).  I get that service in London isn't spectacular, but when its "optional" 12.5% gratuity on top of the regular included gratuity, I'd really hope it doesnt take four requests and multiple table bussings and resettings in between to get your simple bill.Sadly, friends from Australia living in london told me it was very disappointing (the ones who could have saved me my time had I learned this prior to my visit), and that they had rushed there, upon hearing about the "aussie chef," and left equally, if not more, disappointed.

T_deyIHUIdCnxUko2omYUg.text: Went here for brunch on a sunday~Completely packed~ full of  yuppies and babies and some couples~ I had their ricotta cheese pancakes with a coffee with soy (they actually warm the soy for you too!) I'm definitely a fan~! so delicious and fluffy~ We sat at the bar and it was still really nice~ can't wait to go back! what i liked: 1. food (ricotta cheese pancakes) 2. ambiance (nice layout with fresh flowers) 3. location (notting hill)

ITUL_3QA5oLbUtJVS2-PMg.text: We came here on a Sunday morning (around 10:30) and there was a pretty long queue. They said it would be forty minutes but only ended up being about 25! I ordered a hot chocolate, which was uniquely served in a glass so you could see patches of chocolate on the inside of the glass. I was also so excited to try the ricotta hotcakes after hearing so many people rave about them! They. Were. Amazing. Light, fluffy, just the right amount of sweetness, and dripping with honeycomb butter (yum) and maple syrup. The portions were generous and I ate as much as I physically could but still had a little leftover. Both of my friends ordered the same thing and they were equally obsessed with the hotcakes but unfortunately that meant we didn't try anything else on the menu. I highly recommend coming here for brunch, all of the food looked delicious, the staff was friendly, and the wait is well worth it.

photos.caption: Photo of Granger & Co - London, United Kingdom. Ricotta hotcakes

k5lZ_QA-k7v6S03cXmTb6w.text: Granger & Co. is one of my favorite spots in Notting Hill.I've had a few meals here now, and all have been delightful.The courgette (zucchini in the States) chips are delish.The pork belly & watermelon salad, amazing - haven't had a better meal-style salad since being in London yet.The orecchiette & italian sausage is surprisingly light and delicious.The linguine & prawn dish could use some acidity (I added lemon and it made a world of difference), but is still good.The banana fritters should not be missed!The atmosphere is great - an easy place to enjoy good food and company.  It does have an modern, upscale air about it, but not in a stuffy way.  And our servers have all been great, even when slammed, which seems to be often!  It's safe to say I'll be back, probably next week.

tyxdE7GpBswlnSfVuK-A2Q.text: Delicious, fresh and great, if expensive food. Manager is obviously enamoured with his own popularity - incredibly rude to the people queuing today in the cold (4 degrees C): "No you can't wait inside, stay out there."

jLnihu3xFOaIWuaFwrZSbA.text: Fresh, clean ingredients. Simple cooking. The menu is split into hot and cold starters.. I noticed a lot of burrata- yum. Then there are a couple of pasta and rice dishes, mains included fragrant fish curry, lobster with chilli and lime, aubergine parmesan and each day they do a dish of the day.I had a linguine (felt homemade-good texture) with prawns chilli and lime. The pasta was full of flavour, and I liked seeing the very authentic and liberal use of olive oil. Occasional bursts of heat from the chopped chillis. I was left feeling very satisfied.The atmosphere is clean, light and airy, the room is open plan. The menu is not overly expensive and the portions are spot on! You can't reserve here but we had no problem getting in!

jGEO6C27h37Yh9tqGeKyoA.text: A phrase popped into my head as I was crunching away on their homemade cereal--cereal that was so hard to chew, that by the time I gave up trying, my upper jaw was experience exhaustion tremors. That phrase is: mediocrity abounds. And not just at this place, but at most breakfast places on Westbourne Grove. Or maybe it's just something about this space. Pix before it was no good either.The space itself is calm and airy with its buttery walls and architecturally interesting wood and wicker chairs. The bar is where it was when this place was still Pix, but it now has a neutral wood finish--very Scandinavian-looking. We were sat in a corner and then forgotten about for about 20 minutes. Well, that's not completely true; fresh-squeezed orange juice and my flat white came before then, but then there was waiting. We were busy discussing life plans, so I can't say for sure how much times passed, but I did notice after awhile that the three tables around us had been filled with occupants, who showed up after us and had their orders taken before us. After managing to flag down our waiter, who took our order--for me: the homemade cereal with yoghurt and honey, for the hubs: the gravlax with 'curd' on rye--there was more waiting. It was a solid half-hour of pure waiting. At that point, I was praying to all things holy that the food would be worth the wait. It wasn't. Damn! As I mentioned earlier, the cereal was so far beyond crunchy, I thought I might break a molar. And then they brought some milk for the cereal, and it didn't get any less crunchy. How the hell is that scientifically possible? A sad dollop of yoghurt with honey was served alongside. The gravlax was the least smoked fish I've ever encountered. And the curd, oh lord, the curd... where did it come from and what beast could have possibly produced such tasteless milk? Seriously, it didn't taste like anything. I'm a big believer in the power of salt, and even salt could not revive this curd. Between the service and the food, I can't say I'll ever go back. I imagine it will stay open only because of its weekend breakfast option and the crowd that frequents this part of town. For some people it's more about the socialising than the food. Unfortunately, I prefer good food, and there are other places in Notting Hill that do it better.

rv1yV24-hXD8aunPve3LIQ.text: The ricotta hot cakes are amazing! The mushrooms in the Aussie big breakfast are really good and the highlight of the dish. :) My friends and I walked passed this place, which was a stone throw away from our hotel. There was a queue on Sunday so we made it a point to return on a weekday to try it and its seriously very good. The cappuccino is one a must-have for coffee drinkers. I will defintely come back again the next time I am in London!

Photo of Granger & Co - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Granger & Co - London, United Kingdom. Amazing cappuccino! Eagerly waiting for our food.

z-UEpIdkoK3z-ZzyHGtOdw.text: I'm surprised people have written bad reviews of this place, though I didn't eat anything.The atmosphere of Granger & Co is so inviting. I was sitting at the bar planning for trip around Europe, drinking their good selection of beers. I didn't feel bothered about sitting by myself at all because the staff are so nice. It wasn't overly busy in the afternoon, somewhere between lunch and dinner. I've seen it completely packed every time I've walked passed too, which is another indication that people may be more inclined to write bad reviews over good ones. As far as hospitality in London goes in London, Granger & Co is a step above the rest, which I think is a really important point given just at about every restaurant in London is identically traditional.I would absolutely recommend this place to anyone who appreciates quality.

afZSS19kC4B9BSKiEpSWuw.text: Probably the best food we ate in London! We ordered pasta and a salad, and it was AMAZING! if you're planning on going to Notting Hill, you should totally go to this place. You might need to wait for a couple of minutes to get a table, but it's so worth it. The desserts are really good as well, so if you want to add some extra calories to your lunch, you should order their cupcakes or whatever they have that day! There are a couple of really cute designer stores in the same street too, if you're in to that!

5kWdVNPtHx7viIujZDhZBA.text: I do like Granger & Co. I just don't think it's all that special. My meal was fine, my partner's was far better and I hate having food envy. The surroundings are inoffensive and pleasant. I would go back but I certainly won't be rushing.

fIQMmXMJI908D38UmKw7JA.text: Slightly surprised by the bad reviews for this place. We went for brunch and had a great time. Service was friendly and attentive, food was tasty, bloody Mary's were strong and peppery. Little bit on the pricey side for what we had but not crazy. The only thing that bought the place down was the guys next to us droning on about something boring, that probably means I should stop being nosey.From walking past a lot it is constantly busy so don't expect to roll up and get a table.

DBHpp65SsxqEBilrtMUGyQ.text: Really had high expectations... And the food and service did disappoint, I suppose. Mediocre food, poor condescending wait staff, and pretentious "the only way is Essex crowd" crowd.

xV62p9SpyJwYHdXja3EsHg.text: Great breakfast spot! Really nice ambiance and the staff was friendly. I had the Chili fried egg with bacon on brioche and it was delicious and a step above a regular breakfast sandwich. My boyfriend had the Aussie breakfast which also looked great! Someone sitting next to us got the Ricotta hot cakes which looked outstanding. If I am ever in the area will for sure go back to try those. They also had pretty good coffee and full bar. Overall nice place!

ydeFsrXMsixl_mRRWcoc7Q.text: Not great, was expecting outstanding food but it was just a little expensive and annoying. We we're say near the door which was cold and busy. If you get there at 9am then fine, otherwise spend 40 minutes queuing at 10am and wonder why. Not living up to the hype.

photos.caption: Photo of Granger & Co - London, United Kingdom. The Sunday queue ! 2pm

LvgenAEQeBZMlDl__-hB4w.text: Being French, it is a necessity for me to find a good brunch in a beautiful place everywhere I go. I've been here twice and I must admit it does correspond to my likings! It is an absolutely beautiful place: simple yet luminous and romantic with beautiful flowers, fun 50s chairs and charming quirky lamps.The food is quite good, not the best brunch I ever had (although no one can compete with my father's Sunday homemade brunch) but made with fresh tasty products. It is original and good at the same time.Generally a very nice place, a little brunch gem in Notting Hill.

wgzgcvQP0tGdhTtzDkrHig.text: Nice Australian restaurant, running no reservation policy.You should visit mid-week, before 6:30pm to avoid mile long queues. The kitchen is Thai influenced, which is very characteristic for Ausie cuisine. Fish curry was absolute highlight, and I think that's the only dish that makes it more-or-less worth to spend 30-60 minutes in que outside. Otherwise, pretty simple meals and nothing to mention.

mcvO3wNlYgDgmWFSYhDxUQ.text: Food is good (ricotta hot cakes!) Service is not. I waited 10-15 minutes at the bar & no one stopped to ask me anything. I flagged down a waitress who said she'd come back. I ordered & all was fine with the food. Trying to pay was again hard work.I finally flagged down someone to get my bill. I was then overcharged on my card for items I didn't order. They then refunded me one item at a time. Never apologized & never offered to comp my bill or at the very least the automatic service charge. Not impressed.

kaVP5hJrsmJLwDYyc6wxNw.text: Apparently the owner of this place is an Australian celebrity chef a bit like Gordon Ramsay but without the shouting and swearing.I suppose it shows in his London branch which is a well executed example of how to run a restaurant.It's very popular with the affluent locals even on a Sunday night and offers an interesting menu which changes regularly, with a good wine list to boot.The food is well prepared and the service efficient if a little 'removed' from the diners.The atmosphere and decor is neutral, light and airy, and the only real downside is that you'll often have to queue for a table, which is rare for places this side of the BT Tower.I'm already thinking about my next visit and without having read the previous reviews I'm not quite sure why the average star rating isn't higher. I suppose my review will help boost it at least :)

bfWe4it5nOVaFduQku9RqQ.text: Granger & Co has been on my must-try-brunch-spots list for a while, and it did not disappoint! I went with two friends on a Sunday for brunch, and as expected, we needed to queue. However, the queue wasn't terrible and moved pretty quickly (approx 30 min).I started off with a flat white which was delightful. I also had a bloody mary which fell slightly short of expectations, but it was still decent. In terms of food, I had the sweetcorn fritters on the waiter's recommendation, and couldn't have been happier. One of my friends ordered the ricotta pancakes which were also excellent. In general, loved the relaxed, charming vibe of this spot. The restaurant feels very open with lots of light. The wait staff was also very friendly and attentive.Next up, need to try the scrambled eggs! Perhaps at the Clerkenwell location....

Mvb5-Cw8kwQ1DD-SzF-7rw.text: This place is awesome and delightful--- and very popular.  I was alone, so sat at the bar for delicious breakfast.  Then came back for a very tasty dinner. Really, it's food done well!  And the staff are really nice, too. Thanks!

sbGbWir1HKHS2YDh_WDp5g.text: I from the states.  I love food.  Came here because of reviews.  Tried hotcakes and the scrambled eggs.  It was cool.  I wasn't blown away.  No line cuz I got there early.  Staff was great.  It was super pricey...don't think I return...

hewcZovBWOAUulUjfRDtWw.text: Avocado on rye toast and their Hot chocolate to start a beautiful day in London. Sit at the bar if you can.

PP4SmWS3Giw3ZKWnZY8hjQ.text: We came here on a Wednesday at noon and there still seemed to be a queue. We waited for about 20 minutes before we were seated to a pleasant and airy place. The atmosphere was lively but not too loud. We looked at the lunch menu (which served Brunch items) and everything looked delicious! The definite winner on the menu were the Ricotta Hot Cakes! They were perfectly sweet, topped with maple syrup and served with Bananas, but not too overwhelming. The scrambled eggs were fluffy and satisfying, and had quite an interesting texture (I think they're made with milk). Definitely a must for brunch. Their Greek yoghurt and fruit bowl was excellent and light. Overall, the food was delicious and not overbearing or heavy. A great place for brunch for sure!

Photo of Granger & Co - London, United Kingdom. Ricotta hot cakes!

wd4Z349yPKbD5zlHta_Rzw.text: You know it's good when it's very full at 11 o'clock on a Wednesday! Three of us shared the hotcakes a sandwich and the corn fritters and all of it was outstanding -- we could not pick a favorite. If you want a consistent good meal without out-of-control prices I suggest going here.

559w5WNqL4AUC7xlDJoRWA.text: Highly recommended, people were nice and the food was amazing.You must try the hotcake and the scrambled eggs.

3rwqEDVuudSJhgCWpbYEsQ.text: Situated in the beautiful Notting Hill neighbourhood, Granger & Co is the best place to be for a relaxing Sunday brunch with friends. I tried the Fresh Aussie, which comes with smoked salmon, poached eggs, and avocado, all of which are my favourite brunch foods! My Aussie friend also recommended the Ricotta hotcakes, which is apparently a must-have item here.

nQ9LHF9lnIDb2Nj5bMr54g.text: Lovely place. I know Bill Granger's restaurants from Sydney, and G&Co brings that fresh feel, delicious food plus casual, friendly yet efficient service to London.I had the duck which was the modern fusion (Chinese and French) that I love. The salted caramel and chocolate pot is yum!

706oTcMGcuiKA77I2AnxvA.text: I came here twice in two days (it's 50 feet outside of my office) so my experience may be limited, but I will say: Granger, you've got my vote! Spaghetti with artichoke, mint, and lemon and a side of kale sauteed with chili and lemon. Deee-lish. Warm and lively vibe, even during the day - it just puts me in a good mood.

1e2LpFqFfuq5XvKRflejvw.text: This restaurants is one of those hipstery places full of yuppies having brunch. So it's quite nice because let's face it, yuppies are not dumb, they like nice places. White tables, white floor, white windows and white bar create a great room, although tables are cramped and it was jam packed.The food itself was OK, good quality but nothing special except for the dessert, a pear crumble with hot custard wich was simply amazing. The rest was very fresh but the apettizer and main I ordered had the same sauce and I had trouble finding where the Australian cuisine was (but what is Australian cuisine anyways?).Service could be greatly improved and most of them seemed indifferent towards anybody in the restaurant. Maybe they get a bonus for not smiling, who knows. The host was very nice and tried to accomodate everybody in the queue, however at some point there were 5 tables empty inside and a bunch of people queueing oustide.Overall, this place makes for a good experience and the food is worth giving a try. Maybe next time I'll just come for tea and cakes.

7gYmDe8sXwyUg6ia1dNmKg.text: One of my top brunch places! Yes there is a line on weekends around brunch time but what can you expect it is well known and it is in Notting Hill. The line is worth the wait and it actually goes by pretty fast.The menu has many options and interesting combinations such as corn fritters, ricotta hotcakes, quinoa falafel salad, and different egg dishes.I got the scrambled eggs with bread (you can choose the type of break if you ask) with sides of sliced avocado and tomato. Let me tell you right now the eggs are a-ma-zing. So creamy and filling. They must put a ton of cream in there. Also had the green juice, small size for the price, nothing fantastic but good and refreshing.Lots of families, couples, groups of friends - a little loud to my taste but it is the weekend I guess.In a nutshell: best scrambled eggs award

89IvYF4quiba3cNSGMK0RA.text: We actually went to granger and co as part of a wine tasting evening with greywacke... Food service and wine was excellent.. And all for a very reasonable price..

_mqQo_O2pUMh5YRVsaJGeg.text: We went for lunch a waited in line for about 20 minutes. The hostess was very welcoming- keeping people updated on tables that were coming available. The decor is beautiful and the food was exceptional!

qU7ur5uX2BM18MghL_oH4A.text: Great atmosphere, great service, and really great food! Came here for breakfast during my stay in London. I ordered the broken eggs with spinach, ricotta, and pine nuts. It was delicious! The thick slices of bread served on the side were the perfect match for this dish. My friend ordered the full Aussie breakfast and enjoyed it very much. Would love to come back here as everything on their menu sounded so good.
